NeuronArray.networkNotes: Purpose: This network shows the basic Integrate and Fire (IF) and Leaky Integrate and Fire (LIF) neuron models. The neurons in the upper left rectangle are connected one-to-the-next by synapses of weight of 1.0 so the firing of one causes firing of the next. The three neurons to the right: the left-most is connected to itself so it will always fire. It is also connected to the center neurons with a synapse of weight 0.25. You cans see the color change as it accumulates charge. When it reaches its threshold, it will fire and cause the right-most neuron to fire once every tenth cycle. Below that are a cluster of neurons which show basic digital logic functions of OR, AND, NAND, and XOR and a set-reset flip-flop--the simplest possible digital memory using a logic model of always-firing is "1" and never firing is "0". To the right of that is a similar set of logic circuits using a logic family where "1" is represented by ANY SPIKE and "0" is represented by no spike at all. This uses much less energy because continuous firing is not needed. To the right, the "COUNTER" shows how a few synapses can be configured to count the number of firing neurons in a group. At the bottom center are two circuits for detecting the firing frequency of the input. The left one detects the frequency while the right circuit add the ability so that a single spike is output when a frequency is detected but there is no spike output otherwise. The multiple single-spike outputs are OR'ed together in the "Changed" output. In the top center is a short-term memory circuit which is unique in that it is fast (for neurons) but used firing energy only for read and write operations. This circuit stores 4 bits of memory in the charge of the neurons in the center column. The right side shows two circuits representing the implementation of a knowledge graph in neurons. This is described more fully in the technical paper here: https://futureai.guru/articles/SingleSpike.aspxThings to try: Click the "A" and "B" neurons to exercise various digital logic functions [This will make sense to people with EE and CS experience]. A neuron with a synapse to itself will fire continuously after it is clicked and will stop firing if clicked again. Note that a "1" neuron which always fires is necessary to create an inverter (for NAND). This simple demonstration shows that the Integrate-and-Fire forms a logically complete set. That is, with enough neurons, any digital circuit could be created. Repeat with the "1" ANY SPIKE model. Once you click "A" and/or "B", you need to click "READ" for the logic to perform. Click the "S" and "R" neurons to change the firing state of the flip-flop. This is a fast memory mechanism with this type of neuron model as it stores a bit in a single neuron. In the "Fractional Synapse is frequency divider" circuit, you can right-click the yellow synapse to change the frequency of the output spiking. You can also do this in the frequency-detector circuits at the bottom to observe that the output shifts with the change in input frequency. In the COUNTER, select different combinations of "R" neurons and notice that the appropriate output neuron always indicates the number of neurons which are firing. The right-most column eliminates noise in the output with additional suppressing synapses but is not strictly necessary. To use the "Short-Term Memory" circuit, click one or more "SET" neurons to store information. Click "READ" and observe that the memory content is set to the "Out" neurons. To store a new value, click "Clear" to clear all memory cells. Because the bits are stored in the internal charge of the LIF neurons, it decays over time and needs to be refreshed periodically with a "READ"--just like DRAM. You can control the speed of the engine with the slider at the top of the screen. To the left, the << button resets the engine and reinitializes any modules, the || button pauses the engine, and the >| single steps the engine.You can build your own network: Right-click any neuron or synapse to see its state and edit it. You can use the checkbox to add more neurons to the firing history window. You can drag waveform labels up and down in the history window to reorder the waveforms. You can change the model used to calculate a neuron's function. You can drag the mouse cursor from one neuron to another to create a new synapse. You can zoom and pan the neuron display by holding the Shift key and using the mouse wheel or dragging the display. You can also use the scrollbars or the buttons below the main menu bar. Notice that this network is 30x15 or 450 neurons but the simulator works with millions.. When the mouse cursor is between neurons it changes to a cross and you can then drag to select a group of neurons. You can then move to a clear neuron area, right-click a neuron and select Clipboard->Move Here to move the neurons. Other standard clipboard commands also work. If you change the model of a neuron within a selected area, all neurons in the selection are changed. Holding the Shift key while selecting lets you create a selection with multiple rectangles.Current state of development: This network represents the basic neuron models, engine operation, and user interface and is reasonably robust. Please report any bugs you encounter.Some known bugs: If you cut-paste-move a group of neurons to an area which overlaps itself or other neurons, problems may occur. The only models which work through the user interface are Std, LIF, and Random. Others are only useful programmatically. Network size is limited only by RAM and CPU performance. User-interface performance degrades with the number of neurons on the display, not the number in the network which has been tried with millions. In rare instances, a neuron display color will show an erroneous firing state. This is corrected by panning or zooming the display

Neuron.Label: Synapse of wt one causes next neuron to fire
Basic logic family with "1" = ALWAYS SPIKING
Rt-click yellow synapse to change weight
Basic logic family with "1" ANY SPIKE
Conversion of frequency change to single-spikes
Stores value in state of neuron charge
Spikes only when reading or writing
Stores in-use state in Habbian Synapes
